description.narrative: Sustainable natural resource use and forest management in key mountainous areas important for globally significant biodiversity

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: 1.1 Area (ha) of protected areas within the Ugam-Chatkal and Gissar snow leopard landscapes under a more secure, and effectively managed, monitoring and enforcement regime 1.2 Area (ha) of high altitude mountain pasture areas within the Ugam-Chatkal and Gissar snow leopard landscapes under sustainable management for reduced degradation 1.3 Improved conservation status of biodiversity important forests within targeted Protected Areas 1.4 Number of primary snow leopard prey populations within the Ugam-Chatkal and Gissar snow leopard landscapes: a. Siberian Ibex (LC) b. Siberian roe deer (LC) c. Boar (LC) d. Menzbier’s marmot (VU) e. Long-tailed marmot (LC) 1.5 Total snow leopard population within the snow leopard landscapes of Uzbekistan 1.6 Number of women (as a proportion of the total) involved in, and directly benefiting from project investments in the conservation and sustainable use of high altitude montane habitats and species within the Ugam-Chatkal and Gissar snow leopard landscapes 1.7 Coverage of comprehensive, up-to-date baseline environmental and land use information for the snow leopard distribution range 1.8 Quality and coverage of snow leopard monitoring data in Uzbekistan as indicated by estimated accuracy and timeliness of national snow leopard population estimate 1.9 Total extent (ha) of core conservation areas managed as IUCN Category I or Category II protected areas within the Ugam-Chatkal and Gissar snow leopard landscapes 1.10 METT scores for: a. Chatkal SNR b. Ugam-Chatkal State National Nature Park (excluding Chatkal SBR) c. Gissar SNR d. Ugam Chatkal State Biosphere Reserve (Ugam Chatkal SBR) 1.11. Total number (of which are women) of individuals from targeted villages who have completed project funded skills training courses 1.12. Legal or regulatory mechanism in place to pilot Pasture User Associations 1.13. Number of PUAs with approved pasture management plans under implementation in the high altitude pastures of the Ugam-Chatkal an

comment.narrative: 1.1. 116,710 ha 1.2. <5,000 ha Based on GEF-6 PMAT Tracking Tool 1.3. 0 ha 1.4 Siberian Ibex: 3,800-4,000 Siberian roe deer: 250-300 Boar: >1,838 Menzbier’s marmot: 4,300 Long-tailed marmot: 7,994 1.5. ~50 1.6 N/A 1.7 Limited availability of up-to-date environmental information 1.8 Latest population estimate 14 years prior (2003) with a 40% confidence level (lowest possible estimated population / highest possible estimated population, i.e. 20/50 = 40%) (as published in GSLEP) 1.9. 116,710 ha 1.10 Chatkal SBR: 42 Ugam-Chatkal State National Nature Park: 24 Gissar SNR: 43 Chatkal SBR: 0 (newly created reserve) Based on GEF-6 Tracking Tool METT scorecard. 1.11 N/A 1.12 No 1.13. 0 PUAs 1.14 N/A 1.15 Forests: <100 ha 1.16 N/A 1.17 No (outdated, not approved, not implemented and not monitored) 1.18. 0% 1.19. 1 event annually 1.20 No formal international agreement between Uzbekistan and neighboring countries related to snow leopard conservation

1.7. Up-to-date data regarding at least 6 types of environmental data added to BCIMS (Biodiversity Conservation Information Management System) for Ugam Chatkal and Gissar snow leopard landscapes. 1.8. Quality of snow leopard monitoring data in Uzbekistan improved for Ugam Chatkal and Gissar snow leopard landscapes. 1.9. Protected areas management improved for Western Tian Shan and Gissar snow leopard landscapes. 1.10. and 1.11. Smart patrol system introduced and initiated in Uzbekistan. 1.13. Community involvement in, and beneficiation from, protected areas enhanced. 1.14. Legal and regulatory mechanism in place to pilot Pasture User Associations. 1.15. One PUA with approved pasture management plan under implementation in the high altitude pastures of the Ugam Chatkal snow leopard landscape. 1.16. At least 4 households/institutions directly benefiting from project technical and grant funding support for sustainable pasture and livestock management. 1.17. Conditions for active rehabilitation and restoration of degraded high altitude forests of the Ugam Chatkal and Gissar snow leopard landscapes created. 1.18. At least 4 households/institutions directly benefiting from project technical grant funding support for sustainable forest management. 1.19. Final draft of the programme and action plan on snow leopard conservation suubmitted to Government for approval. 1.20. Border security officials received in-service wildlife monitoring and enforcement training and skills development in Ugam Chatkal and Gissar snow leopard landscapes. 1.21. At least two international events related to snow leopard and mountain ecosystem conservation where Uzbekistan is represented and presents infromation on project activities. 1.22. At least one transboundary meeting held to discuss cooperation and coordination with Uzbekistan border countries regarding illegal wildlife trade, biodiversity management in borderland protected areas, and snow leopard monitoring.

1.7. BCIMS (Biodiversity Conservation Information Management System ) platform was uploaded and installed in State Ecology Committee’s server. Respective staff has been trained on use of the BCIMS. Up-to-date data on 7 types of environmental data (e.g. biodiversity, administrative data, land use, ecosystems, biodiversity threats) added to the BCIMS.
1.8. An analysis of data on winter concentrations of prey species of the snow leopard in the Western Tien Shan and Pamir Alai conducted. The presence/absence and abundance of the snow leopard and the main types of preys were studied in spatial cells, with emphasis on peripheral cells in the Western Tien Shan and Pamir Alai to select the most promising for monitoring. Data were obtained on the distribution of snow leopard and prey species as part of a large-scale survey on transects in the spring-summer and autumn-winter periods. As a result of a field survey of the spatial cells of the snow leopard, data were obtained on the presence and quantity of Siberian ibex, Siberian roe deer, wild boar and two species of marmots, snowcocks, chukar in the Western Tien Shan and Pamir Alai, and data on threats was also collected. Camera traps have been installed (in the Pskems and Chatkal ranges) for conducting a local survey using the catch-recatch method to determine the distribution and abundance of the snow leopard. The first recordings from camera traps from the Pskem sub-region were received. 3 snow leopards have been identified. As part of the study and monitoring of the snow leopard, fecal samples are being collected for DNA analysis. To this end, training workshops were conducted for field experts on the collection and storage of genetic samples. The training workshops were held on June 12-18 and July 8, 2019 together with the staff of the Panthera Foundation, the Center for Advanced Technologies of the Ministry of Innovation of the Republic of Uzbekistan and the Academy of Sciences of the Republic of Uzbekistan. Seven samples of potential snow leopards were selected for population analysis. As a result of the analysis, genetic data on the individuals of the snow leopard living in Uzbekistan were obtained for the first time - three samples belonging to this species were revealed. Field trainings were conducted for the staff of the PAs (UCHGNPP, Chatkal State Biosphere Reserve, Gissar State Reserve) on monitoring the snow leopard and prey species. “Instructions for monitoring the snow leopard in the Protected Areas of the Republic of Uzbekistan” have been developed for further inclusion in the management plans of the protected areas. Trainings for forestry and hunting concessions staff is planned for 2020.
1.9. Buffer zone of Gissar State Reserve was created in the area of 11231,3 ha. Draft documents are developed for creation of a new protected area in upper reaches of Tupalang and Sangardak rivers in Surkhandarya region. Anti-poaching group “BARS” was created within State Ecology Committee to improve the inspection work in snow leopard landscapes.
1.10. and 1.11. SMART patrol system was introduced and is being tested in two pilot protected areas, Gissar State Reserve and Chatkal State Biosphere Reserve. The inspectors of these two pilot protected areas have received training on work with the SMART patrol system. 69 staff of PAs were trained on SMART patrol system (23 in Chatkal State Biosphere Reserve and 46 in Gissar State Reserve). In addition, the members of anti-poaching group (five) were also trained on SMART patrol system.
1.13. Skills needs of local communities identified and skill development courses will be launched in 2020. Mainly the local communities are interested in developing the following skills: 1) vet services, 2) aquaculture development, 3) growing medicinal herbs, 4) eco-tourism/guest house, 5) sewing techniques for women, 6) carpentry, 7) auto repair services.
1.14. Pasture Law was approved by the President of the country (№ ЗРУ–538 dated 20 May 2019). Moreover, the mechanism of establishment of associated form of pasture use.
1.15. “Muminobod Chorva” pasture use association was created in Akhangaran disitrct of Tashkent region (Ugam Chatkal snow leopard landscape) with approved pasture management plan.
1.16. A vet service was established with grant and technical support of the project for local communities. The vet service will serve 11 villages located around the Gissar State Reserve.
1.17. A set of tree nurseries (7 in total) with 2 ha each was created by the project within forest enterprises located in two snow leopard landscapes (Western Tian Shan and Pamir Alay). Native tree species will be grown in these nurseries for forest restoration activities.
1.18. A bakery shop was established in Pskem valley to serve 3 villages. The bakery shop will reduce the communities’ need for firewood thus reducing the pressure on natural forests in the mountains.
1.19. The Snow Leopard Programme and Action Plan has been circulated amongst the respective stakeholders for comments. Comments received by various stakeholders are integrated into the document and to be provided to the Government with a draft Resolution in 2020 per NBSAP action plan for 2019-2028.
1.20. Training materials and guidebook finalized for customs and border control officials. Actual trainings will take place in 2020.
1.21. Two international events were attended on snow leopard conservation: “International Science Conference on snow leopard conservation”, 2-3 July, 2019 in Nur-Sultan, Kazakhstan, and “4th Steering Committee of GSLEP”, 23-24 October 2019, in New Delhi, India.
1.22. Prerequisites for the transboundary meeting for customs and border control officials created. It has been agreed with the partners that the meeting will take place in 2020.

1.7. Mini-atlas produced with maps showing up to date environmental information related to biodiversity, pastures, and forests in Ugam Chatkal and Gissar snow leopard landscapes. 1.8. Latest snow leopard population estimate within 2 years prior with a >50% confidence level. 1.9. Proposals for zoning the territory to enhance biodiversity conservation prepared and submitted to partners for implementation. 1.10. and 1.11. The SMART patrol system tested in pilot PAs and recommendations prepared for the implementation of Smart patrol for all PAs of the country. 1.13. Skills training courses conducted for individuals from targeted villages. 1.14. Legal and regulatory mechanism in place to pilot Pasture User Associations. 1.15. Pasture management plans prepared for sustainable management of high altitude pastures of Ugam Chatkal and Gissar snow leopard landscapes. 1.16. Households/institutions in Ugam Chatkal and Gissar snow leopard landscapes directly benefited from project technical and grant funding support for: (a) improving the health and well-being of free-ranging livestock; (b) development of alternative local income generating green enterprises; and (c) establishment of intensive livestock farms. 1.17. Forest restoration activities carried out in at least 500 ha of degraded highland forests. 1.18. Households/institutions in Ugam Chatkal and Gissar snow leopard landscapes directly benefited from project technical and grant funding support for: (a) establishment and maintenance of small plantations/woodlots; (b) establishment of food-producing fruit and nut orchards and herb gardens; and (c) installation and maintenance of alternative energy and fuel technologies and systems 1.19. Final draft of the programme and action plan on snow leopard conservation suubmitted to Government for approval. 1.20. 20% of border security officials received in-service wildlife monitoring and enforcement training and skills development in Ugam Chatkal and Gissar snow leopard landscapes. 1.21. At least two international events related to snow leopard and mountain ecosystem conservation where Uzbekistan is represented and presents infromation on project activities. 1.22. At least one transboundary meeting held to discuss cooperation and coordination with Uzbekistan border countries regarding illegal wildlife trade, biodiversity management in borderland protected areas, and snow leopard monitoring.

1.7. Mini-atlas was planned to be produced this year. A contract was concluded with the consultant to prepare the atlas based on secondary data and in coordination with national partners, however due to the consultant had to resign owing to health issues, this output is shifted to the following year. 1.8. The project has installed camera traps in snow leopard landscapes, namely in snow leopard transects for more and in detail data analysis and research on snow leopard species. Moreover, the project conducted a series of training workshops on snow leopard scat collection and research. The final draft of the snow leopard research and monitoring programme is developed for approval by the Government. Partners are equipped with computers and other IT equipment to carry out data analysis and processing on snow leopards. Training was conducted on analysis of snow leopard DNA from fecals for researchers of Zoology Institute and other Academia representatives. 1.9. A contract is concluded between UNDP and State Cadaster Committee for establishment of a buffer zone of Chatkal State Biosphere Reserve to strengthen biodiversity hotspots and establish an ecological corridor between the Ugam Chatkal State Biosphere Reserve and Chatkal State Biosphere Reserve that are isolated in the meantime. The buffer zone will connect these two isolated protected areas to provide a safe ecological corridor for movement. It is planned to provide the draft buffer zone concept to the Government end of this year. 1.10. and 1.11. The SMART patrol system testing was launched early this year by State Ecology Committee chairman’s order following the training conducted the year before. However, due to pandemic situation in the country and changes that took place within the State Ecology Committee related with changes in management personnel, the testing of the system was not sufficiently successful this year. However, the system was presented to the new NPC, first deputy chairman of State Ecology Committee, and it was welcomed well by the new management of the Committee. It is planned to conduct a refreshment training on SMART patrol this December for protected area staff, namely inspectors. Further, more unfolded testing of the system is expected to resume the following year. 1.13. This activity was not carried out due to pandemic situation in the country. It will be resumed the following year. 1.14. Ideally, the legal and regulatory mechanism is already in place with the adoption of the Pasture Law by the President of the country in 2019. However, the project worked to developed guidelines on practicing and forming associated form of pasture use for communities this year. The guidelines were developed this year, however they were not discussed widely with participation various experts in area of pasture use and management due to pandemic situation. The discussion of the guidelines will be carried out the following year and will be provided to partners for adoption. 1.15. Pasture management plans were developed this year for 8 pilot forest enterprises in consultation with them. However, these pasture management plans were not widely discussed with respective partner agencies and beneficiaries. It is planned to conduct roundtable discussions to finalize the management plans and hand over to partners/beneficiaries for adoption. 1.16. This activity is related with the project microgrants programme (MGP) which was conducted this year. The call for proposals were advertised in mid-year due to pandemic situation. Verification mission was organized by the project to the project sites to study the sites of the proposed applications. Selection of the projects is carried out via Selection Panel and per approved MGP Concept for 2020. Procurement activities are shifted to the following year. 1.17. Forest restoration activities were carried out in 2730 ha of forest land, including in degraded highland forests, and in addition there was natural regeneration of forest in 300 ha in Akhangaran state forest enterprise. 1.18. This activity is related with the project microgrants programme (MGP) which was conducted this year. The call for proposals were advertised in mid-year due to pandemic situation. Verification mission was organized by the project to the project sites to study the sites of the proposed applications. Selection of the projects is carried out via Selection Panel and per approved MGP Concept for 2020. Procurement activities are shifted to the following year. 1.20. Border security officials did not receive in-service wildlife monitoring and enforcement training and skills development this year due to pandemic situation. This activity is shifted to the following year. 1.21. Due to world pandemic situation, Uzbekistan participated in one online international event, GSLEP Steering Committee meeting, related snow leopard and mountain ecosystem conservation organized by GSLEP during 23-25 October 2020, represented by State Ecology Committee. 1.22. No transboundary meetings were held this year as the MOU on transboundary cooperation was not signed by participatory Central Asian countries except Uzbekistan (last year) and Tajikistan (October, this year). With Uzbekistan and Tajikistan officially signing the MOU, and Kazakhstan endorsing it last year, and awaiting Kyrgyz Republic’s response, it is planned to initiate the talks and cooperation between these two countries the following year. Moreover, it is planned to initiate the transboundary cooperation among Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyz Republic and Uzbekistan the following year either online or offline.

1.8. A number of innovative and nature-based solutions introduced for snow leopard and biodiversity monitoring. 1.14. and 1.16. A number of Technical Assistance Programme low-value grant project identified. 1.17. A ten-year Snow Leopard Action Plan approved. 1.18. A number of law enforcement officers e.g. Customs, Border security, Internal Affairs trained on illegal wildlife trade. 1.20. A transboundary MOU on Snow Leopard Conservation signed by at least two Central Asian countries.

1.8. The project developed the Snow Leopard monitoring SMART application to increase the efficiency of animal survey, specifically the snow leopard and its prey, and monitoring in snow leopard landscapes. A training workshop was organized on the use of the application for pilot protected areas, Gissar state reserve and Chatkal state biosphere reserve. The application was tested in the field and primary feedback collected. The project also introduced a computer software for protected areas that are working with the camera traps. The software would facilitate the work of the protected area staff on sorting the pictures from the camera traps. Nowadays, the protected areas have to manually look through every picture out of hundreds of thousands to identify an animal and this process takes days. The introduced software does the work for the reserve staff. It automatically identifies the pictures with animals. This increases efficiency of the work of the reserve staff. In addition, the project also developed a separate SMART application for monitoring of biodiversity in Uzbekistan, which is different from the one developed for Snow Leopard and its prey species. This SMART application for survey and monitoring of wildlife can be used to survey and monitor any biological species.
1.14. and 1.16. In 2021, a number of workshops were conducted for mountain communities in Surkhandarya region on TAP and the communities were trained on application filling and applying for low value grant project financing. 191 applications were received for review and selection by the approved Selection panel, and 33 applications were ultimately selected for financing in order to introduce alternative sources of income and green as well as nature-based solutions to local communities. 1.17. The Cabinet of Ministers (government) has approved an Action Plan on Snow Leopard Conservation for 2021-2030. This is the first country strategic document that focuses on conservation of one biological species in the history of Uzbekistan. Under the umbrella of this document, state agencies and ministries from various disciplines unite and work together to implement the Action Plan. The Action Plan was issued in AUG, 2021. (CabMin №05/1 – 220 from 14 AUG 2021). 1.18. Overall, 127 law enforcement officers were trained on illegal wildlife trade per CITES guidelines. The training also covered the national procedures on how to file for an illegal act on wildlife trade and how to report the cases. 1.20. A Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on Transboundary Cooperation on Snow Leopard Conservation in Western Tian Shan and Pamir Alay landscapes in Central Asia has been endorsed and signed by Central Asian countries, namely Uzbekistan, Kyrgyz Republic and Tajikistan. This is the first in the history of Uzbekistan an MOU on transboundary cooperation on biodiversity conservation that has been signed. Moreover, it is on transboundary cooperation on conservation of a one biological species, the snow leopard. The MOU was signed within the frameworks of UN Climate Change Conference (COP 26) in Glasgow, UK that took place during 31 October – 12 November 2021.

1.1. The SMART patrol system tested in pilot Protected Areas and recommendations prepared for the implementation of SMART patrolling system for all protected areas of the country. 1.2. Pasture management plans for 8 forestry entities finalized for sustainable management of high-altitude pastures of Ugam Chatkal and Gissar snow leopard landscapes. 1.8. Snow leopard monitoring methodology approved by stakeholders. 1.9. Creation of a new PAs in Surkhandarya region approved by the Government and recommendations on the creation of a core zone of the Ugam-Chatkal State National Natural Park are included in the relevant Government decision. 1.11. Skills training courses conducted for at least 200 individuals from targeted communities. 1.14. At least 15 technical assistance projects implemented to support households (average of ~6 individuals/household) in the Gissar snow leopard landscapes inter alia: (a) improving the health and well-being of free-ranging livestock; (b) development of alternative local income-generating enterprises; and (c) establishment of intensive livestock farms. 1.15. Forest restoration activities carried out in at least 1000 ha of degraded highland forests. 1.16. At least 15 technical projects implemented to support households (average of ~6 individuals/household) in the Gissar snow leopard landscapes inter alia: (a) establishment and maintenance of small plantations/woodlots; (b) establishment of food-producing fruit and nut orchards and herb gardens; and (c) installation and maintenance of alternative energy and fuel technologies and systems
